title: The Daily Show - The Snacks of Life

comments.text:
What with the economy and all, I'm more concerned about starving people 
with nothing to eat at all than unhealthy food turning Americans into a 
bunch of dinosaurs. Our number one goal should be making sure everybody 
gets a bite to eat, the healthiness of the food is secondary.

Unfortunately, unhealthy food is what most poor people can only afford, and 
even then many of them still can't afford food at all. Some people are 
killing themselves with extreme intake of calories, others get no calories 
at all. That's the problem.﻿
comments.author: Sakuragi Rokurouta

comments.text:
As a Dietetics major, its very disappointing to see that The Academy of 
Nutrition and Dietetics (AND which I happen to have an active membership 
for) support Kraft Singles Cheese (which isn`t even made out of real 
cheese) by permitting the Kids Eat Right label on their packaging. However, 
many members of the Academy have lobbied against this case. I hope that the 
AND refrains from any future use of permitting labels on packaging of other 
food company`s that would misrepresent the Academy`s obligation towards the 
public`s overall health and nutrition. It does`t come as a surprise that 
money drives people and some organizations to commit unethical decisions.   
#ANDDisappoints   #WeLiveAndWeLearn  ﻿

comments.author: Light of God

comments.text:
While making food healthier is a noble cause the average person does not 
understand the chemicals that are added to the food. This just reminds me 
of the idiot "food babe" who pushed Subway to remove azodicarbonamide from 
their breads. It is true that it is used to make yoga mats, but she was 
disingenuous and basically implied that Subway was adding bits of yoga mat 
to bread. In bread it is used as a stabilizer that results in firm bread 
that does not crack. This dim bulb also once stated, "There is just no 
acceptable level of any chemical to ingest, ever." For those of us that are 
actually aware that everything is chemicals; this should give you a 
headache. 

As for the donuts, the chemical that makes them brighter is Titanium 
Dioxide and it is an inactive ingredient. It does not harm you to ingest 
the chemical in food. It is a class 2B carcinogen like azodicarbonamide 
or caramel color level IV. Class 2B means that "the agent (mixture) is 
possibly carcinogenic to humans." There is not enough evidence to claim it 
is carcinogenic, but there is a possibility that it may be carcinogenic.﻿

comments.author: madman3470

comments.text:
The irony is, probably the only thing that would convince me, a Dane, to 
visit the US, braving gun-toting cops, crime, American air travel 
practices, etc., would be the almost satanically appealing foods I'd get to 
eat for a week.

Suffice it to say, most American food chains haven't found success 
marketing products to the Danes, most of whom tend to gag if they ingest 
too much grease. Which is why it'd be fun to travel over a thousand miles 
to indulge myself safe in the knowledge that I'll never be tempted to eat 
like that in my regular life.﻿

comments.text: What does artificial chemicals mean?﻿
comments.author: Adam G

comments.text: IT MEANS NOTHING!
comments.author: cravenjooooooooooooo

comments.text:
+kerafill1116 You can't get rid of those types of preservatives if you need 
your food to last for extended periods of time. Refrigeration has little to 
do with it. Like I said there's more to it than health, and things like 
preservatives are good depending on the situation. And as I said earlier, 
some people can't have certain chemicals that are vital, so alternatives 
are always helpful.
comments.author: Adam G

comments.text:
+Adam G But nowadays, you can do away with those types of preservatives 
with proper refrigeration.  And there are always natural alternatives.  But 
if you are largely dependent on canned goods, then information is half the 
battle won.  But like I said, even if you informed yourself sufficiently, 
the other end still has limitations as I've stated above, which makes it 
inherently bad whether you know it or not.
comments.author: kerafill1116

comments.text:
+kerafill1116 By extend life span I meant the food's life span. 
Preservatives are a huge asset depending on people's situations. And 
whether or not "side effects" (completely different connotation to me, as I 
think medication. I'd pre negative health effects) are labeled is a problem 
with government regulations, corporations, and consumer negligence. Has 
nothing to do with the fact that man made chemicals can be good or bad.
comments.author: Adam G

comments.text:
+Adam G I get what you mean. From a broader sense, the distinction between 
whether natural or synthetic is better is hard to determine.

But when it comes to food, I really don't trust artificial flavors much. 
 1)  The studies almost always conveniently omits any side effects to 
physical/mental health in favor of better marketing.  2)  The study 
timespan is too short to observe any potential physical/mental alterations.

I still eat fastfood occasionally though.  Lol.
comments.author: kerafill1116

comments.text:
+kerafill1116 I was talking specifically about what he contributed in his 
comment I could have read verbatim on the wiki article about Opiates. 

Again, the ONLY problem I had was the statement "natural is better." That's 
just an ignorant statement. Some chemicals are needed to prolong life span, 
other's are supplements (or substitutes) for a diet. When you want to make 
a point about a specific chemical then by all means. Or if you want to bag 
on processed foods and their poor production ethics, again go ahead. As I 
said earlier, it was that only statement I had a problem with.
comments.author: Adam G

comments.text:
+Adam G It's not really a blanket statement as you had put it.  Reading 
about it in wiki does not help the general understanding acquired from 
experience.  You see, man still have primitive manufacturing techniques in 
synthetic chemicals as we still use hydrocarbons in petrochemicals as 
drsomeone1 stated.  Industrial uses are quite practical.  But for food, 
it's not organic and needless to say, incompatible with our digestive 
system.  Until we get to figure out the more complex advanced tricks the 
way nature does it *naturally*, the artificial flavors we make is not 
really that healthy compared to natural ones.
comments.author: kerafill1116

comments.text:
+drsomeone1 When you put a blanket statement like that it comes off as if 
man made chemicals are inherently harmful. It's okay to talk about the 
disadvantages of specific chemicals, but to say "natural chemicals are 
better" is just ignorant.
comments.author: Adam G

comments.text:
ok this is my last response. i talked about specific chemicals, from my 
first response where i mistakenly tried to be helpful: " (a lot of times 
they use petrochemicals as basic building bulks), they are in general 
harmful," this is the problem with alot of additives, cheap harmful basic 
substances.
If you didnt grasp the meaning of "in general"when i talked about 
artificial stuff and specifically petrochemicals and in no way meant "made 
by man then inherently harmful" then again i dont know what to say, any way 
take care.
comments.author: drsomeone1

comments.text:
+drsomeone1 You didn't have to talk about chemistry whatsoever. It's a very 
straight forward subject. If I wanted to know about opiates I'd just read 
the wiki article and find exactly what you put in your reply.Just know that 
just because it's man made doesn't automatically mean it's unhealthy. 
Nobody needs that opinionated shit. Speak about specific chemicals. Blanket 
statements like that just make you sound incredibly uneducated or 
anti-science.
comments.author: Adam G

comments.text:
at the beginning i figured this is what you have problem with but then i 
said to my self it cant be it as it is so obvious i was talking about 
chemicals used in food as the whole video was talking about it, and in the 
same time explaining how the body handle them and the artificial stuff must 
be another clue.
 it is clear snake's poison is a natural chemical but it is lethal, you 
dont need clarification for that, so when i say "better" i mean natural 
additives in food compared to artificial chemicals in food, thats why they 
are preferred, not giving a whole chemistry lessons. even one of the 
responses (kerafill1116) was indicating that artificial chemicals is 
artificial flavor, because the whole subject is about food.
if you understood that by better i meant even cyanide is better than 
artificial additives then i dont know what to say, i didnt know i must give 
chemistry lecture. any way i dont want to open a discussion, i am sorry i 
 was trying to be helpful, my mistake.
comments.author: drsomeone1

comments.text:
+drsomeone1 I just quoted the part that was wrong. Just because something 
is found in nature doesn't automatically mean it's better. Cyanide will 
kill you and that's found naturally in many plants. When you give such a 
blanket statement I can't take you seriously. All I want is facts, not some 
seemingly opinionated bs being flung my way.
comments.author: Adam G

comments.text:

The alternative would be to raise animals under more humane and healthy 
conditions - but that costs money - money some greedy assholes obviously 
are unwilling to spend.
One big problem in feeding all animals on huge amounts of antibiotics is 
that this creates multi-drug resistent bacteria.
If these get in contact with children or elderly people, they can kill them 
- and no hospital in the world can help, since not even antibiotics can 
kill those bacteria.
So in other words: The mass-production of meat is breeding a deadly monster.

comments.author: kuribo1

comments.text:
+kuribo1 Titanium Dioxide is the most commonly produced and used pigment in 
the world used in a variety of industries because it is cheap, easy to use 
and is relatively unreactive in and outside of the human body. The safety 
data sheet for TiO2 only lists possible skin and lung irritation as major 
danger when working with pure pigment powder and classifies titanium 
dioxide as stable in all other areas. Optical brighteners, like titanium 
dioxide, merely reflect more light so that an object (be it paper or 
toothpaste) appears more white. The active ingredient in sunscreen is 
titanium dioxide because that's how sunscreen works- by reflecting more of 
the sun's rays away from the skin. 
Also, the claim that TiO2 is a class two carcinogen, while true, is 
unnecessary fear mongering. Titanium Dioxide is a class 2B carcinogen, 
which means that in the right circumstances (in this case very fine 
particulate matter and a poor ventilation) it is possible that the 
substance may be linked to cancer. To be considered a class 2B carcinogen 
means there has been no actual proof levied that the substance actually 
causes cancer.

+J Taylor
There a number of reasons people choose to go vegan:
1. Health (Watch Forks Over Knives or read the numerous studies and books 
on the health effects of vegan diets.)
2. Environmental (as mentioned by gjul)
3. Moral, animal rights
4. Moral, hunger. Over half of all wheat produced in the US goes to feed 
livestock. Roughly, 90% of soy, oats, and other grains are also fed to 
livestock. If you freed up all that grain every person on the planet could 
get 1 cup of grain a day. Hunger is not due to lack of food resources but 
the distribution of food resources. Privileged people would rathr feed food 
to cows rather than to starving humans just so they can eat their steak. 
5. Labor rights. Slaughterhouses are one of the worst industries with the 
highest turnover. They are dangerous physically as well as psychologically. 
In terms of health, these workers have a higher rate of cancer and this is 
due to aerosolized meat and blood.

comments.author: David Foster

comments.text:
+Sean Monaghan I don't know whether or not the substance contains powdered 
sugar, but the way it usually work is that the company will take a 
traditional practice, like topping donuts with powdered sugar, and try to 
"improve" it by adding various chemicals - artificial sweetners and fillers 
to reduce the reliance on sugar, reducing the calorie count, additives to 
make it taste slightly "better", additives to alter the texture or colour, 
as well as preservatives to keep it edible for longer during storage.
Long-term storage, I should point out, is particularly profitable because 
it prevents waste and allows for a more centralized, specialized production 
(since goods can be transported further and still be stored locally before 
spoiling.)
Some of these additives are common and exist in traditional cuisine. Some 
are derived from biproducts of other food production, and some are 
synthesized in a lab - which doesn't necessarily mean it's unhealthy or 
unnatural, although scepticism is in order.
My guess is they've replaced half the powdered sugar with flour, then added 
artificial sweeteners and preservatives to make up for the lost flavour and 
preservative effect of the sugar, and then added something - maybe a mix of 
things - that makes the sugar seem less dry and more savoury. The result is 
that they can cut some 50 calories off the donut and make it taste more 
savoury, making it more addictive (and, I suppose, more tasty). Both will 
tend to make business sense if large scale production can be undertaken.
None of this is supposed to be an endorsement. I would much prefer getting 
donuts from a locally-owned business where they actually make the things 
themselves using ingredients you'd find in a supermarket.
comments.author: Emil Sørensen

comments.text:
+king worldstar That is very un-Dutch of you to insult America. After all 
America is the Netherland;s longest ally. I live in what used to be New 
Netherlands. I am sure your grandparents did not insult the Americans in 
September 1944. Now on the comedic side- Who the hell ever heard of Mark 
Rutte outside of Holland? I went to the Netherlands and never heard his 
name once. (now ex-) Queen Beatriz and King William and Queen Maxi (vamos 
Argentina carajo!) are much more famous. I am American and am not fat 
because I do not eat fast food (NY Pizza is food done fast-there is a 
difference) , I know how to cook and try to eat seasonally and locally. 
Dutch food is greasy and fattening too, the difference is EU food quality 
laws, bitterballen, friekendal, panekokken, worstenbrood or anything at 
FEBO isn't diet food. (I love the haring) . Even the Indonesian food loaded 
with palm oil and coconut milk of a fatty doner made with lamb belly flaps 
aren't that healthy. If AMericans rode bicycles like the dutch do they'd be 
just as slim.
